subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Acronyms and Abbreviations
msgSnippet: Personally, I just spell out these acronyms as they re spoken.  My thinking is that even illiterate persons know what the Yoo-es-ay is, so as long as we
messageBody:
Personally, I just spell out these acronyms as they're spoken.  My thinking is that even illiterate persons know what the "Yoo-es-ay" is, so as long as we apply that name to the country, we can spell it as we say it.

-Benjamin Bruce

2007/11/14, Terry Smithwick <Tinyallen@...>:

I've seen this brought up before, and my favorite
solution is in common with names.
Simply spell each acronym using the alphabet it was
created in.
I also prefer to write each name in the way the
owner wrote it, adding a QS-style approximation of the
name's pronunciation if appropriate.

This means that stretches of QS will be
interspersed with Latin (or Hebrew or Cyrillic or
Kanji or . . .) letters, which I accept as inevitable
- until QS takes over completely, mwua-ha-ha.

Spelling out the spoken version of the acronym
(You-Ess-Ay for USA) is my second-favorite method.
While longer, it does have the advantage of
familiarity once it's sounded out. Hyphens or another
punctuation mark will be required to tie the parts
together.

The other options I recall involve spelling out the
words the acronym stands for (with a parenthetical new
acronym for that discussion), or transliterate the
'usual' sounds of each letter.

I particularly dislike the last option.

--- Ron Cameron <ronwcameron@...> wrote:
> I'm sure this has been discussed before, but how
> does one handle acronyms and/or abbreviations in QS?
>
> For example, how to handle things like NASA, NOAA,
> UK, CIA, i.e., e.g., cf., and so on?

 ===========
Never insult anyone by accident.
- Robert A. Heinlein
